lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
We'll now look at the textarea element, which allows users to input and edit more text.

A textarea element is perfect for when you need more than a single line of text input.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To begin with, add a self-closing textarea element.

Make sure to pick <, followed by textarea, and finally />.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's make it more usable by adding some placeholder text. Give users a hint of what to write.

Add a placeholder with the text "Enter text...". Really helpful, no?

Make sure to pick placeholder, followed by =, and finally "Enter text...".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We'll need to update the React component state whenever the textarea element changes. We'll use the useState hook.

Add a state variable text and initialize it with an empty string.

Make sure to pick const, followed by [text, setText], and finally useState("").

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now, let's complete the handleChange function to update our state.

Complete the handleChange function to update the state variable text with the value from the target of the event that triggered it.

Make sure to pick handleChange followed by event and then setText, event.target.value.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To trigger the handleChange function, we need to call it when the text is changed.

Add an onChange attribute that calls our handleChange function.

Make sure to pick onChange, followed by handleChange.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finally, let's display the length of the input text live under the textarea element.

Display the length of the state variable inside an embedded expression to give immediate feedback.

Make sure to pick { followed by text and then ., length, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the correct way to add a textarea element in React?

<textarea /><textarea></textarea><textarea><input type="textarea">

<textarea />.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a textarea element to allow users to input text about their favorite coding course.

Make sure to type textarea.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be displayed under the textarea?

The number of characters typedThe content of the textareaNothing will be displayedAn error message

The number of characters typed.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Implement a textarea with a placeholder and an event listener.

Make sure to pick textarea followed by placeholder and then onChange, handleChange.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which React hook should you use to manage state when using a textarea?

useStateuseEffectuseReduceruseLayoutEffect

Make sure to pick useState.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the useState hook to create a textarea that allows users to write about their favorite book. Display the character count below.

Make sure to pick const followed by [bookText, setBookText] and then useState, "", handleInput, setBookText, onChange, handleInput.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the onChange event do in a textarea element?

It triggers a function when the content of the textarea changesIt disables the textareaIt changes the color of the textareaIt initializes the textarea with default text

It triggers a function when the content of the textarea changes.
